qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I use it for WhatsApp voice messages to my customers, to take pictures of clothes I stitch, and sometimes for YouTube sewing videos. My daughter helps me with new things.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, my eldest daughter uses it for schoolwork, and my husband uses it if his phone isn’t working.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: WhatsApp is useful for talking and sending stitched photos. YouTube gives me ideas for new designs. I don’t know what they take from my phone.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like access to location or contacts, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No, I just click ‘OK’ because I don’t know what it means. I ask my daughter if something looks confusing.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: If my daughter or sister-in-law uses it, then I also feel it’s okay.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: Yes, I delete some WhatsApp messages if I think my husband will misunderstand.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I remove the memory card and hide some photos in another folder.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, I always ask my daughter. I don’t mind her seeing messages or photos—she knows everything.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I only trust face-to-face. Even on the phone, I feel someone may be listening.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Yes, sometimes I say ‘blue cloth’ when I mean something else in front of the kids.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: I’ve shown another tailor how to send voice messages on WhatsApp.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera or location?
qa.answer: No, my daughter might know.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I close the app and ask my daughter what to do.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: Maybe it uses them to help me. I never thought they could go somewhere else.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, once I waited for my daughter to delete some messages before we went.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: I don’t know. I hope not. I never checked after repair.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: No, it’s too confusing. I just keep the phone with me.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: Maybe Indian ones are better because the language is easy.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: My daughter or my niece.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my sister-in-law told me not to give bank details online.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I ask my daughter to remove photos and messages before giving it to the shop.
scenarios.Sharing a Phone with Family: If a private message comes, I quickly open it myself and then delete it.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I ask my daughter first. If she says yes, only then I do it.
scenarios.Helping an Elderly Relative: I’ve helped my mother use WhatsApp, but I didn’t explain permissions. She won’t understand.
scenarios.Using a Borrowed Phone: If I see a private photo, I look away and never say anything.
scenarios.Selling or Giving Away a Phone: I’d delete WhatsApp and photos, but don’t know how to format the phone.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I’d be shocked. I didn’t know that deleted things could still be online.
scenarios.Using Free Public WiFi: I don’t use WiFi in public. My daughter told me it’s not safe.
scenarios.Receiving a lottery: I got one once. I laughed and cut the call. My niece had warned me.
scenarios.Sharing account details: I will only send money if my daughter says it’s okay. I don’t know how to check properly.
